## AWS Disaster Recovery Cheat Sheet

- RTO is the time it takes after a disruption to restore a business process to its service level.
- RPO is the acceptable amount of data loss measured in time before the disaster occurs.
- Disaster Recovery With AWS

Backup and Restore â€“ storing backup data on S3 and recover data quickly and reliably.

![AWS Disaster Recovery 1](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

Pilot Light for Quick Recovery into AWS â€“ quicker recovery time than backup and restore because core pieces of the system are already running and are continually kept up to date.

![AWS Disaster Recovery 2](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

Warm Standby Solution â€“ a scaled-down version of a fully functional environment is always running in the cloud

Multi-Site Solution â€“ run your infrastructure on another site, in an active-active configuration.

- AWS Production to an AWS DR Solution Using Multiple AWS Regions â€“ take advantage of AWSâ€™ multiple availability zones

## Services

- [S3](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-s3/) as a destination for backup data that might be needed quickly to perform a restore.
- Import/Export for transferring very large data sets by shipping storage devices directly to AWS.
- [Glacier](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-glacier/) for longer-term data storage where retrieval times of several hours are adequate.
- Server Migration Service for performing agentless server migrations from on-premises to AWS.
- Database Migration Service and Schema Conversion Tool for moving databases from on-premises to AWS and automatically converting [SQL](https://tutorialsdojo.com/azure-sql/) schema from one engine to another.
- [Storage Gateway](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-storage-gateway/) copies snapshots of your on-premises data volumes to S3 for backup. You can create local volumes or [EBS](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-ebs/) volumes from these snapshots.
- Preconfigured servers bundled as Amazon Machine Images (AMIs).
- [Elastic Load Balancing (ELB)](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-elastic-load-balancing-elb/) for distributing traffic to multiple instances.
- [Route 53](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-route-53/) for routing production traffic to different sites that deliver the same application or service.
- Elastic IP address for static IP addresses.
- [Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC)](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-vpc/) for provisioning a private, isolated section of the AWS cloud.
- [Direct Connect](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-direct-connect/) for a dedicated network connection from your premises to AWS.
- [Relational Database Service (RDS)](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-relational-database-service-amazon-rds/) for scale of a relational database in the cloud.
- [DynamoDB](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-dynamodb/) for a fully managed NoSQL database service to store and retrieve any amount of data and serve any level of request traffic.
- [Redshift](https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-redshift/) for a petabyte-scale data warehouse service that analyzes all your data using existing business intelligence tools.
- [CloudFormation](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-cloudformation/) for creating a collection of related AWS resources and provision them in an orderly and predictable fashion.
- [Elastic Beanstalk](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-elastic-beanstalk/) is a service for deploying and scaling web applications and services developed.
- [OpsWorks](https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-opsworks/) is an application management service for deploying and operating applications of all types and sizes.

## AWS Disaster Recovery Cheat Sheet Reference:

[https://www.slideshare.net/AmazonWebServices/disaster-recovery-options-with-aws](https://www.slideshare.net/AmazonWebServices/disaster-recovery-options-with-aws)
